A Practical Guide to Antibiotics

Published on January 25, 2025 | By JW

Antibiotic coverage chart. Source: teachIM.org.

Antibiotics are one of the few domains over which the general internist still commands jurisdiction. In medical school, I was drawn to microbiology/antibiotics thanks to Sketchy. I have found that medical students and interns alike often feel hesitation with antibiotic selection, borne at least in part out of learning several dozen microbes and their pharmacological counterparts and mechanisms of action in the classroom in a haphazard manner, and in part out of a habit of using a specific but seemingly arbitrary set of antibiotics on the wards that depends highly on institutional habits but devoid of any sensible structure. Here I’ll share a simplified but practically high-yield framework for thinking about antibiotics in the inpatient setting. As an early trainee, you will immediately add value to many medicine teams and most non-medicine teams (I’m looking at you, surgery, AKA the Ancef aficionados) by wielding your antibiotic scepter with confidence.

As always, be familiar with your institutional practices, stay up to date with your local antibiogram trends, and keep your pharmacy and ID colleagues close. Use nuance, of which the approach described herein lacks, when making clinical decisions.

Bacterial Classifications

Roughly, we will approach different clinical classes of bacteria as follows:

  • Gram-positive (G+): thick peptidoglycan cell wall that retains crystal violet Gram stain; includes Staph (which includes MSSA and MRSA), Strep, and Enterococcus (which includes VRE)
  • Gram-negative (G-): thin peptidoglycan cell wall that does not trap crystal violet but does retain pink/red counterstain; includes PsA and ESBLs
  • Anaerobes: thrive in environments with little or no oxygen; includes gut flora like Bacteroides, Clostridium, and Fusobacterium
  • Atypicals: poorly Gram stained due to atypical/absent cell wall or intracellular dwelling; includes Mycoplasma, Chlamydia, and Legionella
  • Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA): G+ coccus resistant to methicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics due to a modified penicillin-binding protein (PBP), encoded by mecA gene
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa (PsA): G- rod with predilection for water and humid conditions (e.g., hot tubs, lakes, contaminated contact lens solution); risk factors include cystic fibrosis, diabetes, indwelling catheters, mechanical ventilation (VAP), IVDU (endocarditis/osteomyelitis), and burn wounds (SSTI)
  • Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE): E. faecalis and E. faecium resistant to vancomycin by acquisition of van genes
  • Extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs): usually G- rods (e.g., Escherichia coli, Klebsiella spp.) that produce beta-lactamases that cleave beta-lactam antibiotics (penicillins, cephalosporins, and rarely carbapenems)
We could discuss endlessly the nuances of these classes (as well as many others not covered), but the basics above are sufficient for our purposes here.

Overview to Antibiotics

In the panels below, bacterial classes are color-coded; when following "~", this indicates that the preceding antibiotic(s) provides appropriate coverage of that class, and when following "∅", this indicates inadequate coverage. We will start by reviewing the constituents of two major classes of β-lactam antibiotics, followed by the coverage options for the common bacterial classes explored above. For the purpose of discussing common coverage patterns (particularly the gaps in a given regimen), we will exclude VRE and ESBLs as these classes tend to be less common and more severe in presentation than the others. Therefore, our simplified framework will consist of six main bacterial classes: G+, G-, anaerobes, atypicals, MRSA, and PsA. When recalling the coverage pattern of a specific antibiotic or regimen, think about which of these classes it covers and which of these it doesn't.

  • Penicillin: IM PCN only for syphilis
  • Amoxicillin, ampicillin: strep throat (GAS pharyngitis), otitis, etc.; ampicillin-sensitive Enterococcus; Listeria meningitis
  • Methicillin, oxacillin, dicloxacillin, nafcillin: MSSA
  • Amoxicillin/clavulanate (PO Augmentin), ampicillin/sulbactam (IV Unasyn) ~ G+, G-, anaerobes
    • ∅ MRSA, PsA, atypicals
  • Piperacillin/tazobactam (IV Zosyn): adds PsA coverage ~ G+, G-, anaerobes, PsA
    • ∅ MRSA, atypicals
    • NB: Pip/tazo confers anaerobic coverage, while cefepime does not
  • "Broad spectrum" = vancomycin + piperacillin/tazobactam ~ G+, G-, anaerobes, PsA, MRSA
    • ∅ atypicals

Note that the earlier generations predominantly cover G+ cocci, while latter generations add G- rods (including PsA).
  • 1st generation. Cephalexin (PO Keflex), cefazolin (IV Ancef) ~ G+ (Strep, MSSA)
  • 2nd generation. Cefotetan (IV/IM), cefuroxime (PO/IV): not routinely used, adds some G- coverage
  • 3rd generation. Cefpodoxime (PO), ceftriaxone (IV; abbrev. CTX) ~ G+, G-
    • ∅ PsA, MRSA, anaerobes, atypicals
  • 4th generation. Cefepime: adds PsA coverage ~ G+, G-, PsA
    • ∅ MRSA, anaerobes, atypicals
    • NB: Pip/tazo confers anaerobic coverage, while cefepime does not
  • "Broad spectrum" = vancomycin + cefepime + metronidazole ~ G+, G-, PsA, MRSA, anaerobes
    • ∅ atypicals
    • Analogous to vanc + pip/tazo
  • 5th generation. Ceftaroline: compared to cefepime, adds MRSA coverage but loses PsA coverage ~ G+, G-, MRSA
    • ∅ PsA, anaerobes, atypicals
  • *3rd generation. Ceftazidime: compared to cefpo and CTX, adds PsA coverage but loses G+ coverage ~ G-, PsA
    • ∅ G+, MRSA, anaerobes, atypicals

  • Clindamycin (PO/IV): covers infections above the diaphragm
    • Increases C. diff risk
    • Bacteriostatic—inhibits toxin synthesis (like linezolid), e.g., Strep and Staph infections complicated by necrotizing fasciitis or toxic shock syndrome
  • Metronidazole (PO/IV Flagyl; abbrev. MTZ): covers infections below the diaphragm
    • Can be used as treatment for C. diff infection (usually second-line tx; first-line = PO fidaxomicin or PO vancomycin)

Mnemonic: FAT
  • Fluoroquinolones: ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, moxifloxacin ~ G+, G-, atypicals, PsA
    • Cipro and levo cover urinary sources; levo and moxi cover respiratory sources
    • Cipro does not cover G+; moxi does not cover PsA
    • Adverse effects: QT prolongation, tendon rupture
  • Macrolides: Azithromycin, erythromycin
    • Azithro covers Legionella, ?increases C. diff risk
    • Erythro often used for its promotility effect (e.g., before EGD in upper GI bleed)
  • Tetracyclines: doxycycline ~ oral anaerobes, atypicals, MRSA
    • Does not increase C. diff risk but does not cover Legionella (vs. azithro)
    • Adverse effects: photosensitivity, pill esophagitis; in children: inhibition of bone growth, ?discoloration of teeth
CAP coverage: e.g., [CTX + azithro] or [CTX + doxy] ~ G+, G-, atypicals

Inpatient / Hospital
  1. Vancomycin
  2. Daptomycin
  3. Linezolid
Outpatient / Community
  1. Bactrim
  2. Clindamycin
  3. Doxycycline
Others
  • Ceftaroline
  • Tigecycline
Mnemonic (convoluted AI-generated): Vans Don't Last, Cars Tire Daily, Clean Bacteria
Vanc Dapto Linezolid / Ceftaroline Tigecycline / Doxy Clinda Bactrim

Consider reviewing the rest of the panels before returning to this one, as PsA coverage is best remembered by antibiotic class.
  • PCNs: pip/tazo
  • Cephalosporins: cefepime, ceftazidime (not ceftaroline)
  • FQs: ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin (not moxifloxacin)
    • These are the only PO options
  • Carbapenems: meropenem, imipenem, doripenem (not ertapenem)
  • Aminoglycosides: gentamicin, amikacin, tobramycin (not streptomycin)
  • Aztreonam: covers G- aerobes and PsA, use when pt has a PCN allergy (no cross-reactivity with PCNs as it is a monobactam)
Mnemonic: MAFIA Pseudomonas Challenges Clinicians
Meropenem Aztreonam FQs (not moxi) Imipenem Aminoglycosides Pip-tazo Cefepime Ceftazidime

  • Daptomycin ~ G+, MRSA, VRE
    • No lung coverage (e.g., PNA) d/t inactivation by surfactant
    • Adverse effect: rhabdomyolysis (trend CK)
  • Linezolid (PO/IV) ~ G+, MRSA, VRE
    • Bacteriostatic—antitoxin effect (like clindamycin)
    • Adverse effects: pancytopenia (esp. tcp) 2/2 bone marrow suppression, serotonin syndrome (nonselective MAOI)

  • Carbapenems: meropenem, imipenem, doripenem ~ G+, G-, anaerobes, PsA, ESBLs
  • Carbapenems: ertapenem: does not cover PsA ~ G+, G-, anaerobes, ESBLs
    • qDaily IV dosing (vs. meropenem q8h)
  • "Broad spectrum" = vancomycin + carbapenem (except ertapenem) ~ G+, G-, anaerobes, PsA, MRSA, ESBLs
    • ∅ atypicals
    • NB: This regimen covers ESBLs, unlike [vanc + Zosyn] and [vanc + cefepime + Flagyl]

Closing Thoughts

There exists no shortage of charts, articles, and textbooks expounding on every last clinical and biochemical detail of the above antibiotics (and many others not explicated). The goal of this beginner's guide is practicality and clarity: you must memorize these basics to make basic clinical decisions involving antibiotics and to develop a more advanced understanding of these drugs and the organisms they target. I hope this concise framework empowers you with the confidence to do these things. I urge you to learn the fundamentals with sufficient familiarity that you may teach your own medical students and juniors this content from memory, incorporated with your own clinical experience and pearls.
